channel.title: Tag: webdev - blog.lmorchard.com
channel.description: It's all spinning wheels & self-doubt until the first pot of coffee.

item.title: Sketches as Web Components
item.description: <html><head></head><body>For years, I've tinkered with game development on the web. But, I haven't finished (m)any games. So, I decided to just focus more on finishing little interesting sketches of graphics and sound. This time around, I'm playing with portals—er, I mean Web Components</body></html>

item.title: Sketches as Web Components
item.description: <html><head></head><body>For years, I've tinkered with game development on the web. But, I haven't finished (m)any games. So, I decided to just focus more on finishing little interesting sketches of graphics and sound. This time around, I'm playing with portals—er, I mean Web Components</body></html>

item.title: Clustering ideas with Llamafile and Web Components
item.description: <html><head></head><body>TL;DR: In my previous posts, I tinkered with a few variations on clustering ideas by named topics using embeddings and text generation. In this post, I'm going to show off a web UI that I built to make this stuff easier to play with interactively.</body></html>

item.title: I like automations for inclusive development
item.description: <html><head></head><body>TL;DR: I like deploying robots to include more of the team in our core development loop</body></html>

item.title: Animating Mermaid diagrams with terrible hacks
item.description: <html><head></head><body>So, I wanted to produce a GIF animation of a graph diagram changing over time. What I came up with wasn't the slickest result, but it's close enough to what I'd initially imagined.</body></html>

item.title: How to build your own Easy-Blog Oven
item.description: <html><head></head><body>TL;DR: I wanted to write more about building my Easy-Blog Oven. I mainly glued together things I already knew, but I think I learned some things and had some surprises anyway.</body></html>

item.title: Easy-Blog Oven
item.description: <html><head></head><body>TL;DR: I made a new static site generator for my blog. It's not very clever. I've been calling it my "Easy-Blog Oven" and it seems to be working well so far.</body></html>

item.title: Fun with Themes in Firefox
item.description: <html><head></head><body>TL;DR: Last year, I started work on a new Test Pilot experiment playing with themes in Firefox.</body></html>

item.title: Firefox Test Pilot: The Flattening
item.description: <html><head></head><body>TL;DR: Firefox Test Pilot is becoming a statically-generated site from content in flat files. We're moving away from Django and PostgreSQL, and it's been a bit of a journey.</body></html>

item.title: Continual Blogployment
item.description: <html><head></head><body>Ever since I switched this blog over to a Gulp-based toolchain - holy crap, 2 years ago - I had a TODO to wire this thing up for continual deployment. Well, today I finally did it.</body></html>

item.title: Adding Android to a multi-platform React app
The web is awesome
item.description: <html><head></head><body>TL;DR: The open web is a beautiful thing that empowers makers while offering users leverage. There's nothing else like it. It's constantly improving. It's up to you what you do with it.</body></html>

item.title: Experimenting with a multi-platform app using React
item.description: <html><head></head><body>TL;DR: I built a toy app using React for web and native to get a feel for whether this hybrid approach is worth using. I think the answer is "yes" - but mainly for apps whose business logic & data models are more complex than their views.</body></html>

item.title: The Verge's web sucks
item.description: <html><head></head><body>TL;DR: Did you know that The Verge delivers you to around 20 companies for advertising & tracking purposes? I didn't. That might foul up your web experience a little bit. Maybe we should try something different.</body></html>

item.title: Parsec Patrol Diaries: Construction Time Again
